title: My Pineapple Tallow Balm Experiment: What Actually Happened to My Skin
body:
Look, my skin was just… mad at me. This was back in, I don’t know, January? The whole winter thing. My face felt tight all the time, like I was wearing a mask made of drywall. My knuckles were cracking. I was using that fancy cream from the department store, the one in the blue jar that costs like eighty bucks. Didn’t do a thing. I was scrolling on my phone one night, probably around 11:47pm, and I saw this thing about beef tallow balm. For your face. I thought it was a joke. Beef fat? On my skin? Sounded like something my grandma would have used, or like, a weird survivalist thing. But the person talking about it seemed normal. And my skin was so over everything else. So I figured, what’s the weirdest thing that could happen.

I found this little shop on Etsy. “Whipped Tallow Balm - Pineapple.” Made in France, from grass-fed cows. It was like thirty-something dollars. Less than half a tank of gas. I ordered it. A week later, this little jar shows up.

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face

The jar was cute. Simple. I opened it. Smelled like… pineapple. But not like candy. Or cleaner. More like if you walked past a fruit stand that had really ripe pineapples. It was cheerful. Like a vacation smell in a jar. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold butter. You scoop a little and it melts instantly from your finger heat. I was standing in my bathroom, in my sweatpants, thinking “I am about to smear cow fat on my face. This is a new low.”

But I did it. Just on my cheeks and forehead that first night. It felt… oily for a second. Then it was just gone. Absorbed. My skin didn’t feel greasy. It felt quiet. That’s the only word I have for it. The tight, itchy feeling just stopped. I went to bed expecting to wake up with a face full of zits.

I didn’t.

Okay, where was I. Right. So I started using it for my **natural skincare routine**. Just at night. After a few days, I put it on my hands. The cracks on my knuckles, which I’d been slathering with that thick, white, medicinal stuff from the drugstore, started to actually heal. Not just get less bad, but like, smooth over. I was shocked. The whole **switching to natural products** thing always seemed like a hassle, but this was just one jar. One step.

## Why This Pineapple Tallow Balm Just… Works

I looked it up because I was curious. Beef tallow, when it’s from grass-fed cows and whipped up like this, is apparently really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top like a silicone blanket—it gets in there. It makes sense, I guess. We’ve been using animal fats forever. Lard for cooking, tallow for candles and soap. It’s only recently we decided chemicals with fifteen-syllable names were better.

The pineapple scent is the best part, though. It doesn’t smell like beef. At all. It just smells like summer. It’s that **tallow balm daily use** thing that makes a difference. You don’t need much. A tiny scoop for your whole face. The jar lasts forever. My eighty-dollar cream sat on my shelf for a month until I finally threw it out. Felt good, actually.

My skin after a few weeks wasn’t “glowing” in that Instagram way. It wasn’t a dramatic transformation. It was just… normal. It wasn’t tight when I woke up. It didn’t get angry and red when I came in from the cold wind. The little dry patch I always had near my eyebrow just vanished. My hands looked like human hands again, not a lizard’s. I started using it on my elbows, too. They haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid, I don’t know when.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Stuff Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar now. I got one for my mom too, for her eczema on her arms. She texted me last week like “what is this magic potion.” I told her it’s fancy cow fat. She didn’t believe me.

The weather’s been weird lately. One day it’s freezing, the next it’s weirdly warm. My skin usually freaks out with these changes. This winter, it just… didn’t. I don’t have a ten-step routine anymore. I wash my face with a basic cleanser, I put on this tallow balm. That’s it. Sometimes in the morning if my skin feels dry, I’ll use a tiny bit. It’s simple. My bathroom counter isn’t crowded with bottles. I like that.

Anyway, if you’re curious about this whole tallow thing, the shop I got mine from is on Etsy—just search for the Pineapple one. It’s a small operation. The jar is simple. It just works. I don’t know what else to say.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. Because it’s so close to what our skin already produces, it absorbs deeply and helps repair your skin barrier. It’s not just a surface-level moisturizer. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks it actually knows how to use.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience, and I can get clogged pores pretty easy. Since it mimics sebum, it absorbs cleanly. It doesn’t just sit there and suffocate your skin like some heavy creams do. My skin actually feels like it can breathe.

**What does the pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like ripe pineapple, but not in a fake, sugary way. It’s a bright, fruity, vacation kind of smell. It’s cheerful. It doesn’t smell like beef at all, which was my biggest worry. It just makes the whole experience feel a little more fun.

So yeah. If your skin is being difficult, especially in the winter, this might be worth a shot. It’s one of those things that sounds too strange to work, but then it just… does. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
random_tangent: the weather has been weird lately
